byline.contributor: Aaron M. Kessler reported from Ann Arbor, Mich., and Coral Davenport from Washington.
byline.original: By AARON M. KESSLER and CORAL DAVENPORT

abstract: Environmental Protection Agency is expected to propose regulations that would cut greenhouse gas emissions from heavy-duty trucks by requiring up to 40 percent increase in fuel economy by 2027, compared with 2010 levels; regulations will require innovation from truck manufacturers and have caused concern among some in trucking industry.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to propose rules requiring heavy trucks to increase their fuel economy by up to 40 percent by 2027.

headline.main: E.P.A. Proposal Will Put Bigger Trucks on a Fuel Diet
headline.print_headline: E.P.A. Will Put Bigger Trucks on a Fuel Diet

snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to propose rules requiring heavy trucks to increase their fuel economy by up to 40 percent by 2027.
